newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - July 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - July 11.

text.p: Following are the highlights of Irish press on Friday:

- The Orange Order's withdrawal of plans to march through key sectarian flashpoints was greeted with widespread relief and seen as a significant step in easing tension between the two communities in Northern Ireland.
- The government intends to resist opposition pressure to set up a second tribunal exclusively to investigate whether former prime minister Charles Haughey received monies from private donors.
- State-owned transport company CIE plans to seek fare increases on its bus, DART and rail services before the end of the year.
- The Orange Order moved to secure a peaceful July 12 by cancelling or relocating a series of parades.
- Bus and rail fares are likely to rise by an average of 2.5 percent following poor trading figures by CIE.
- Fine Gael is expected to hunt for evidence to back up opposition demands for a wider inquiry into the source of former prime minister Charles Haughey's personal fortune.
- Japan's Asahi closed its 315-job plant in County Mayo after allegedly learning that staff had rejected proposals for a management buyout of the company.
